channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: A DNA clutch controls a golden nanomachine
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00408-x

The engine of a microscopic motor can be coupled or uncoupled from the rotor by means of DNA coatings that respond to a variety of stimuli.
item.dc:title: A DNA clutch controls a golden nanomachine

item.title: Ultrafast, nanoscale control of electrical currents using light
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00362-8

Tailoring symmetries in an innovative class of optoelectronic metasurface produces a rich landscape of tunable current patterns down to the nanoscale. These materials provide opportunities for ultrafast light-controlled charge flows that could have applications in terahertz science, information processing and other realms.
item.dc:title: Ultrafast, nanoscale control of electrical currents using light

item.title: A massive galaxy that formed its stars at z ~ 11
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07191-9

A massive galaxy that formed its stars at z ~ 11
item.dc:title: A massive galaxy that formed its stars at z ~ 11
item.dc:creator: Karl Glazebrook

item.title: A high black hole to host mass ratio in a lensed AGN in the early Universe
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07184-8

A high black hole to host mass ratio in a lensed AGN in the early Universe
item.dc:title: A high black hole to host mass ratio in a lensed AGN in the early Universe

item.title: Great ‘Stone Age’ wall discovered in Baltic Sea
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00409-w

Megastructure stretching nearly 1 kilometre long is probably one of the oldest known hunting aids on Earth.
item.dc:title: Great ‘Stone Age’ wall discovered in Baltic Sea

item.title: Smoking changes your immune system, even years after quitting
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00482-1

The lingering effect of cigarettes on T cell responses, and the Solar System's new ocean.
item.dc:title: Smoking changes your immune system, even years after quitting
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: What a tease! Great apes pull hair and poke each other for fun
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00410-3

The animals’ shenanigans hint that mischievous play evolved well before Homo sapiens did.
item.dc:title: What a tease! Great apes pull hair and poke each other for fun

item.title: Nuclear morphology is shaped by loop-extrusion programs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07086-9

In neutrophil progenitor cells, stopping the process of loop extrusion by depleting nipped-B-like protein (NIPBL) results in the assembly of polymorphonuclear structures and the activation of a neutrophil-specific gene program.
item.dc:title: Nuclear morphology is shaped by loop-extrusion programs
item.dc:creator: Indumathi Patta

Lindsay Lee

Cornelis Murre

item.title: A new family of bacterial ribosome hibernation factors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07041-8

A study identifies a new bacterial ribosome hibernation factor, Balon, and describes its association with EF-Tu and its initiation of mRNA-independent hibernation during protein synthesis.
item.dc:title: A new family of bacterial ribosome hibernation factors
item.dc:creator: Karla Helena-Bueno

Sergey V. Melnikov

item.title: Nuclear export of circular RNA
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07060-5

Circular RNAs are exported from the nucleus by Ran-GTP, exportin-2 and IGF2BP1 in a mechanism analogous to protein export rather than mRNA export.
item.dc:title: Nuclear export of circular RNA

item.title: Structure of human phagocyte NADPH oxidase in the activated state
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07056-1

The cryo-electron microscopy structure of the human phagocyte NADPH oxidase in the activated state provides insight into how cytosolic factors bind to and promote the activating conformational changes of NOX2, facilitating its efficient electron transfer.
item.dc:title: Structure of human phagocyte NADPH oxidase in the activated state
item.dc:creator: Xiaoyu Liu
Yiting Shi
Rui Liu
Kangcheng Song
Lei Chen

item.title: Visuo-frontal interactions during social learning in freely moving macaques
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07084-x

Behavioural tracking and wireless neural and eye-tracking recordings show that freely moving macaques learn to cooprate using visually guided signals along the visual-frontal cortical network.
item.dc:title: Visuo-frontal interactions during social learning in freely moving macaques
item.dc:creator: M. Franch
S. Yellapantula
A. Parajuli
N. Kharas
A. Wright
B. Aazhang
V. Dragoi

item.title: Optimally generate policy-based evidence before scaling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06972-y

To reduce voltage drops—the depreciation of the cost–benefit profile when scaling up solutions to social problems—sufficient policy-based evidence must be generated before policymakers scale up the project.
item.dc:title: Optimally generate policy-based evidence before scaling
item.dc:creator: John A. List

item.title: Influence of pump laser fluence on ultrafast myoglobin structural dynamics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07032-9

Ultrafast time-resolved serial femtosecond crystallography is used to investigate a photodissociation reaction in a protein, revealing the strong impact of the pump laser fluence on the structural changes and the reaction mechanism.
item.dc:title: Influence of pump laser fluence on ultrafast myoglobin structural dynamics

item.title: Online images amplify gender bias
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07068-x

We find that gender bias is more prevalent in images than text, that the underrepresentation of women online is substantially worse in images and that googling for images amplifies gender bias in a person’s beliefs.
item.dc:title: Online images amplify gender bias
item.dc:creator: Douglas Guilbeault
Solène Delecourt
Tasker Hull
Bhargav Srinivasa Desikan
Mark Chu
Ethan Nadler

item.title: Critical transitions in the Amazon forest system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06970-0

Analyses of drivers of water stress are used to predict likely trajectories of the Amazon forest system and suggests potential actions that could prevent system collapse.
item.dc:title: Critical transitions in the Amazon forest system

item.title: Observation of plaid-like spin splitting in a noncoplanar antiferromagnet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07023-w

Examining the in-plane spin components of the noncoplanar antiferromagnet manganese ditelluride provides spectroscopic and computational evidence of materials with a new type of plaid-like spin splitting in the antiferromagnetic ground state.
item.dc:title: Observation of plaid-like spin splitting in a noncoplanar antiferromagnet

item.title: Bone marrow plasma cells require P2RX4 to sense extracellular ATP
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07047-2

We demonstrate the role of the ligand-gated purinergic ion channel P2RX4 in maintaining mouse plasma cells in their bone marrow niche.
item.dc:title: Bone marrow plasma cells require P2RX4 to sense extracellular ATP
item.dc:creator: Masaki Ishikawa

item.title: Genetic determinants of micronucleus formation in vivo
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-07009-0

Genetic screening identifies a rich catalogue of regulators of micronucleus formation.
item.dc:title: Genetic determinants of micronucleus formation in vivo

item.title: Smoking changes adaptive immunity with persistent effects
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06968-8

A survey of 136 factors that may influence cytokine secretion identify smoking, cytomegalovirus latent infection and body mass index as influential factors, with varying effects on innate and adaptive immunity.
item.dc:title: Smoking changes adaptive immunity with persistent effects

item.title: Deep whole-genome analysis of 494 hepatocellular carcinomas
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07054-3

The Chinese Liver Cancer Atlas project depicts a panoramic genomic landscape of hepatocellular carcinoma, covering candidate coding and non-coding drivers, mutational signatures, extrachromosomal circular DNA, subclonal catastrophic events and detailed evolutionary history.
item.dc:title: Deep whole-genome analysis of 494 hepatocellular carcinomas
item.dc:creator: Lei Chen

item.title: A model of human neural networks reveals NPTX2 pathology in ALS and FTLD
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07042-7

A neural stem cell culture system derived from induced pluripotent stem cells forms a network of synaptically connected and electrophysiologically active neurons that were used as a model system to identify a mechanism of TDP-43-induced neurodegeneration.
item.dc:title: A model of human neural networks reveals NPTX2 pathology in ALS and FTLD
item.dc:creator: Marian Hruska-Plochan

item.title: Altermagnetic lifting of Kramers spin degeneracy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06907-7

Using photoemission spectroscopy and ab initio calculations, evidence is given of two distinct unconventional mechanisms of lifted Kramers spin degeneracy generated by the altermagnetic phase of centrosymmetric MnTe with vanishing net magnetization.
item.dc:title: Altermagnetic lifting of Kramers spin degeneracy
item.dc:creator: J. Krempaský

item.title: A 2D ferroelectric vortex pattern in twisted BaTiO<sub>3</sub> freestanding layers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06978-6

The stacking of freestanding ferroelectric perovskite layers with controlled twist angles results in a peculiar pattern of polarization vortices and antivortices that emerges from the flexoelectric coupling of polarization to strain gradients.
item.dc:title: A 2D ferroelectric vortex pattern in twisted BaTiO<sub>3</sub> freestanding layers
item.dc:creator: G. Sánchez-Santolino

item.title: Room-temperature quantum optomechanics using an ultralow noise cavity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06997-3

A room-temperature demonstration of optomechanical squeezing of light and measurement of mechanical motion approaching the Heisenberg limit using a phononic-engineered membrane-in-the-middle cavity with ultralow noise.
item.dc:title: Room-temperature quantum optomechanics using an ultralow noise cavity
item.dc:creator: Guanhao Huang
Alberto Beccari
Nils J. Engelsen
Tobias J. Kippenberg

item.title: A single-cell time-lapse of mouse prenatal development from gastrula to birth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07069-w

Single-cell transcriptome profiling of mouse embryos and newborn pups is combined with previously published data to construct a tree of cell-type relationships tracing development from zygote to birth.
item.dc:title: A single-cell time-lapse of mouse prenatal development from gastrula to birth
item.dc:creator: Chengxiang Qiu

item.title: Rainforest transformation reallocates energy from green to brown food webs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07083-y

Conversion of rainforest to plantations in Sumatra leads to higher energetic losses in animal food webs aboveground than belowground, with the belowground energy being reallocated from diverse arthropod communities to invasive earthworms.
item.dc:title: Rainforest transformation reallocates energy from green to brown food webs
item.dc:creator: Anton M. Potapov

item.title: Autonomous transposons tune their sequences to ensure somatic suppression
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07081-0

SAFB proteins protect genome integrity by preventing retrotransposition of L1 elements yet maintaining splicing integrity, via prevention of the exonization of previously integrated transposable elements, a major constituent of human genes.
item.dc:title: Autonomous transposons tune their sequences to ensure somatic suppression
item.dc:creator: İbrahim Avşar Ilık
Petar Glažar
Kevin Tse
Björn Brändl
David Meierhofer
Franz-Josef Müller
Zachary D. Smith
Tuğçe Aktaş

item.title: Rapid spin changes around a magnetar fast radio burst
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-07012-5

X-ray observations of two large glitches bracketing a fast radio burst in the active Galactic magnetar SGR 1935+2154 reveal a connection between rapid spin change and radiative behaviours of the magnetar.
item.dc:title: Rapid spin changes around a magnetar fast radio burst
item.dc:creator: Chin-Ping Hu

item.title: Non-Abelian topological order and anyons on a trapped-ion processor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06934-4

A trapped-ion quantum processor is used to create ground-states and excitations of non-Abelian topological order on a kagome lattice of 27 qubits with high fidelity.
item.dc:title: Non-Abelian topological order and anyons on a trapped-ion processor
item.dc:creator: Mohsin Iqbal

item.title: The future of precision cancer therapy might be to try everything
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00392-2

Researchers are blasting patients’ cancer cells with dozens of drugs in the hope of finding the right treatment.
item.dc:title: The future of precision cancer therapy might be to try everything
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: This new map of the Universe suggests dark matter shaped the cosmos
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00489-8

The eROSITA telescope’s detailed pictures are among the most precise cosmological measurements ever made.
item.dc:title: This new map of the Universe suggests dark matter shaped the cosmos
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Smoking’s lasting effect on the immune system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00232-3

It emerges from a study of human cells that smoking can influence certain immune responses to the same extent as can age or genetics. Smoking can alter the immune system in ways that persist long after quitting the habit.
item.dc:title: Smoking’s lasting effect on the immune system
item.dc:creator: Yang Luo
Simon Stent

item.title: Daily briefing: Global trust in scientists is high
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00496-9

A survey of more than 71,000 people in 67 countries finds that people trust scientists and believe they should play a bigger role in policy making. Plus, a private Moon landing could finally happen.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Global trust in scientists is high
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Calling all engineers: Nature wants to publish your research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00390-4

Papers in engineering are under-represented, even neglected, in the journal. We want to change that.
item.dc:title: Calling all engineers: Nature wants to publish your research

item.title: Gender bias is more exaggerated in online images than in text
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00291-6

A big-data analysis shows that men are starkly over-represented in online images, and that gender bias is stronger in images compared with text. Such images could influence enduring gender biases in our offline lives.
item.dc:title: Gender bias is more exaggerated in online images than in text
item.dc:creator: Bas Hofstra
Anne Maaike Mulders

item.title: New type of magnetism splits from convention
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00190-w

Magnetic materials with zero net magnetization fall into two classes: conventional antiferromagnets and altermagnets. Physicists have identified a property in altermagnets that widens the divide between the two groups.
item.dc:title: New type of magnetism splits from convention
item.dc:creator: Carmine Autieri

item.title: Introducing meat–rice: grain with added muscles beefs up protein
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00398-w

The laboratory-grown food uses rice as a scaffold for cultured meat.
item.dc:title: Introducing meat–rice: grain with added muscles beefs up protein
item.dc:creator: Jude Coleman

item.title: Welcome aboard the Silva family historic spaceside attraction tour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00334-y

A trip of a lifetime.
item.dc:title: Welcome aboard the Silva family historic spaceside attraction tour
item.dc:creator: Carol Scheina

item.title: Smoking scars the immune system for years after quitting
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00412-1

A cigarette habit and previous infection with a common virus both have important effects on the immune system.
item.dc:title: Smoking scars the immune system for years after quitting
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Energetic laser pulses alter outcomes of X-ray studies of proteins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00233-2

Cutting-edge X-ray sources have enabled the structural dynamics of proteins to be tracked during biochemical processes, but the findings have been questioned. Two experts discuss the implications of a study that digs into this issue.
item.dc:title: Energetic laser pulses alter outcomes of X-ray studies of proteins
item.dc:creator: Richard Neutze
R. J. Dwayne Miller

item.title: Why is Latin America on fire? It’s not just climate change, scientists say
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00471-4

Rampant planting of flammable non-native species has helped to fuel deadly blazes — even in places known for cool, damp weather.
item.dc:title: Why is Latin America on fire? It’s not just climate change, scientists say
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Wight

item.title: Layered ferroelectric materials make waves — and vortices
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00231-4

By combining materials-synthesis techniques, researchers have come up with a way of building layered structures that display intriguing wave-like patterns of electric polarization, and could be useful for next-generation electronics.
item.dc:title: Layered ferroelectric materials make waves — and vortices
item.dc:creator: Berit H. Goodge

item.title: Largest post-pandemic survey finds trust in scientists is high
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00420-1

Study of more than 70,000 people suggests that trust levels vary among countries and are linked to political orientation.
item.dc:title: Largest post-pandemic survey finds trust in scientists is high
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: Topological matter created on a quantum chip produces quasiparticles with computing power
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04126-8

Non-Abelian anyons are emergent quasiparticles found in exotic quantum states of matter, which could have applications in fault-tolerant topological quantum computing. But performing the manipulations necessary to make these quasiparticles has proved a challenge — now overcome through a happy confluence of theoretical and experimental innovation.
item.dc:title: Topological matter created on a quantum chip produces quasiparticles with computing power

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07165-x

Alkene dialkylation by triple radical sorting
item.dc:title: Alkene dialkylation by triple radical sorting

William L. Lyon
David W. C. MacMillan

item.content:encoded:

Build global collaborations to protect marine migration routes
item.dc:title: Build global collaborations to protect marine migration routes
item.dc:creator: Jianguo Du
Bin Chen
Feng Cai
Wenjia Hu

item.title: Deep-sea mining opponents: there’s no free lunch when it comes to clean energy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00404-1

Deep-sea mining opponents: there’s no free lunch when it comes to clean energy
item.dc:title: Deep-sea mining opponents: there’s no free lunch when it comes to clean energy
item.dc:creator: Saleem H. Ali

item.title: The immune markers that predict who can keep SARS-CoV-2 in check
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00411-2

People infected with the virus that causes COVID-19 cleared the virus more quickly if they had high levels of certain immune cells.
item.dc:title: The immune markers that predict who can keep SARS-CoV-2 in check

item.title: Open-access publishing: citation advantage is unproven

Open-access publishing: citation advantage is unproven

Nature, Published online: 13 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00236-z

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: river pollution, and a minister for science

item.title: Indonesian election promises boost to research funding — no matter who wins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00350-y

Scientists regard campaign promises with scepticism, however, and criticize the country’s science super-agency.
item.dc:title: Indonesian election promises boost to research funding — no matter who wins
item.dc:creator: Ardila Syakriah

item.title: Culture wars are raging on US campuses. Will they affect research?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00393-1

Scientists and other academics worry that political pressure on universities is growing and could limit research and teaching.
item.dc:title: Culture wars are raging on US campuses. Will they affect research?
item.dc:creator: Emma Marris

item.title: Private Moon launch a success! But will the craft land safely on the lunar surface?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00419-8

Anxiety is high as the company Intuitive Machines takes its first crack at a touchdown.
item.dc:title: Private Moon launch a success! But will the craft land safely on the lunar surface?
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: EU climate policy is dangerously reliant on untested carbon-capture technology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00391-3

Europe’s ambition for emissions reductions is to be welcomed — but look at the detail, and significant hazards emerge.
item.dc:title: EU climate policy is dangerously reliant on untested carbon-capture technology

item.title: Solitary light pulses on a chip-sized laser open up analytical applications
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04123-x

Self-reinforcing light pulses known as solitons are fundamental structures in wave dynamics. Previously, solitons could be produced only by bench-top lasers, but they can now also be generated using chip-sized mid-infrared lasers. This innovation enables the development of portable, efficient tools for use in spectroscopy, environmental sensing and medical diagnostics.
item.dc:title: Solitary light pulses on a chip-sized laser open up analytical applications

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: AI helps to reveal first passages of ancient charred scroll
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00488-9

Student researchers used machine learning to read text hidden inside charred, unopenable scrolls from the ancient Roman city of Herculaneum. Plus, reviewers accuse scientist of using ChatGPT to write a paper and what scientists think of Apple’s Vision Pro headset.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: AI helps to reveal first passages of ancient charred scroll
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Daily briefing: China’s sweeping retraction audit
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00486-x

In a first nationwide review, China’s universities must tell the government all of their retractions from the past three years. Plus, blood proteins reveal dementia risk and Katalin Karikó’s decades-long fight for recognition.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: China’s sweeping retraction audit
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00395-z

Peter Chatanga uses weeks-long audio recordings to build a picture of biodiversity in Lesotho’s crucial wetlands.
item.dc:title: I listen to the sounds this remote wetland makes to learn its rhythms
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: I run a physics lab — and thousands of kilometres a year
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00369-1

In 2023, Jenny Hoffman ran across the United States in 47 days, smashing the women’s world record. But she still found time to lead a research team.
item.dc:title: I run a physics lab — and thousands of kilometres a year
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: China conducts first nationwide review of retractions and research misconduct
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00397-x

Universities must declare all their retractions and launch investigations into misconduct cases; a Nature analysis reveals that since 2021 there have been more than 17,000 retractions with Chinese co-authors.
item.dc:title: China conducts first nationwide review of retractions and research misconduct
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: Early dementia diagnosis: blood proteins reveal at-risk people
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00418-9

The results of a large-scale screening study could be used to develop blood tests to diagnose diseases such as Alzheimer’s before symptoms take hold.
item.dc:title: Early dementia diagnosis: blood proteins reveal at-risk people
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Postdocs celebrate 24% pay boost in one of the world’s most expensive cities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00407-y

Starting salaries at New York’s Icahn School of Medicine rise to $72,500 as part of a deal led by unionized researchers.
item.dc:title: Postdocs celebrate 24% pay boost in one of the world’s most expensive cities
item.dc:creator: Laurie Udesky

item.title: A researcher-exchange programme made me a better doctor at home and abroad
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00417-w

Caleb Skipper describes how global health collaborations bring valuable transfers of knowledge to both sides of the Atlantic.
item.dc:title: A researcher-exchange programme made me a better doctor at home and abroad
item.dc:creator: Christopher Bendana

item.title: I took my case to Nepal’s highest court to improve conservation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00389-x

After seeing an endangered-animal pelt displayed on television, Kumar Paudel embarked on a five-year legal battle, advocating for equitable enforcement of wildlife laws.
item.dc:title: I took my case to Nepal’s highest court to improve conservation
item.dc:creator: Saugat Bolakhe

item.title: How journals are fighting back against a wave of questionable images
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00372-6

Publishers are deploying AI-based tools to detect suspicious images, but generative AI threatens their efforts.
item.dc:title: How journals are fighting back against a wave of questionable images
item.dc:creator: Nicola Jones

item.content:encoded:

Petunias that contain genes from bioluminescent mushrooms hit the US market. Plus, climatologist wins landmark defamation case and how air pollution turns moths off flowers.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Want a glowing houseplant? Now you can buy one

item.content:encoded:

Personal priorities are often trumping real needs and skewing where charitable funding goes.
item.dc:title: The ‘Bill Gates problem’: do billionaire philanthropists skew global health research?
item.dc:creator: Andy Stirling
